comments.creator: lassey@chromium.org
comments.author: lassey@chromium.org
comments.text:
I'm using the really slow inflight internet and its looking like firefox just can't load any pages. So I launched Safari and it can load pages (still slow, since its a bad network, but they come eventually).

So the main difference between Firefox and Safari at that point is Firefox had lots of tabs open and Safari had just one. So, I killed firefox and restarted it and it was still not loading pages (I've got the bartab preference enabled, so only one tab should be hitting a network in this case).

So I opened a new window and closed the one that had lots of tabs open in it. And finally, Firefox started loading pages. This leads me to believe that we should be able to do better in the "lots of tabs" case. Perhaps prioritizing the traffic of the focused tab??
comments.raw_text:
I'm using the really slow inflight internet and its looking like firefox just can't load any pages. So I launched Safari and it can load pages (still slow, since its a bad network, but they come eventually).

So the main difference between Firefox and Safari at that point is Firefox had lots of tabs open and Safari had just one. So, I killed firefox and restarted it and it was still not loading pages (I've got the bartab preference enabled, so only one tab should be hitting a network in this case).

So I opened a new window and closed the one that had lots of tabs open in it. And finally, Firefox started loading pages. This leads me to believe that we should be able to do better in the "lots of tabs" case. Perhaps prioritizing the traffic of the focused tab??

comments.creator: jduell.mcbugs@gmail.com
comments.author: jduell.mcbugs@gmail.com
comments.text: I'm seeing something similar: on a home network where my ISP (but not my router) kept cutting in and out, firefox spun up to 100% when the network came back *on*.  Didn't get a chance to try to track it down more before the network recovered.
comments.raw_text: I'm seeing something similar: on a home network where my ISP (but not my router) kept cutting in and out, firefox spun up to 100% when the network came back *on*.  Didn't get a chance to try to track it down more before the network recovered.
See bug 710176 and try the patch that I just posted there.
